docs.title: NetBox Insights Dashboard Plugin
docs.text: Universal analytics and operational visibility dashboard for NetBox with vendor-agnostic architecture

docs.title: 🎯 Overview
docs.text: NetBox Insights Dashboard is a powerful NetBox plugin that provides comprehensive operational visibility into your network infrastructure. Built with a vendor-agnostic architecture, it works seamlessly with any network vendor through extensible plugin architecture.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• 📊 6 Core Widgets - IPAM utilization, device health, data quality, predictive maintenance, capacity planning, and topology status
  • 🚀 Zero Configuration Start - Works immediately after installation with sensible defaults
  • 🔌 Vendor Agnostic - Supports any network vendor (Cisco, Juniper, Arista, etc.)
  • 📈 Predictive Analytics - Trend-based forecasting and proactive alerts
  • 🎨 Modern UI - Responsive dashboard with auto-refresh and color-coded status indicators
  • 🔐 REST API - Full API for external integrations and automation
  • ⚡ Performance Optimized - Built-in caching and efficient database queries

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• NetBox 4.0 or higher
  • Python 3.8 or higher

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
1. Activate NetBox virtual environment:
source /opt/netbox/venv/bin/activate
  1. Install the plugin:
pip install netbox-insights-dashboard-plugin
  1. Add to NetBox configuration:

Edit /opt/netbox/netbox/netbox/configuration.py:

PLUGINS = [
    'netbox_insights_dashboard_plugin',
]

PLUGINS_CONFIG = {
    'netbox_insights_dashboard_plugin': {
        'ipam_warning_threshold': 75,
        'ipam_critical_threshold': 90,
        'stale_data_days': 30,
        'trend_period_days': 90,
    }
}
  1. Run database migrations:
cd /opt/netbox/netbox
python3 manage.py migrate netbox_insights_dashboard_plugin
  1. Collect static files:
python3 manage.py collectstatic --no-input
  1. Restart NetBox services:
sudo systemctl restart netbox netbox-rq
  1. Access the dashboard:

Navigate to Plugins → Insights Dashboard in the NetBox UI.

docs.title: 1. IPAM Utilization Dashboard 🌐
docs.text: Monitor IP address and VLAN usage with color-coded threshold alerts.

docs.title: 2. Device Health Monitor 💚
docs.text: Track device health scores and identify data completeness issues.

docs.title: 3. Data Quality & Compliance ✅
docs.text: Monitor data quality with compliance scoring and validation.

docs.title: 4. Predictive Maintenance 🔮
docs.text: Proactive alerts based on trend analysis and capacity forecasting.

docs.title: 5. Capacity Planning 📈
docs.text: Track growth trends and forecast future capacity requirements.

docs.title: 6. Network Topology Status 🔗
docs.text: Monitor network connectivity, cables, and topology health.

docs.title: 🔧 Configuration
docs.text:
Basic configuration example:

PLUGINS_CONFIG = {
    'netbox_insights_dashboard_plugin': {
        # IPAM Settings
        'ipam_warning_threshold': 75,
        'ipam_critical_threshold': 90,

        # Device Health
        'stale_data_days': 30,

        # Predictive Maintenance
        'trend_period_days': 90,
        'forecast_horizon_days': 180,

        # Performance
        'enable_caching': True,
        'cache_ttl': 300,
    }
}

docs.title: 🌐 REST API
docs.text:
The plugin provides a full REST API for external integrations:

# Get IPAM utilization summary
GET /api/plugins/insights/ipam-utilization/summary/

# Get predictive alerts
GET /api/plugins/insights/insights/predictive_alerts/

# Get data quality score
GET /api/plugins/insights/insights/data_quality/

# Push custom metrics (webhook)
POST /api/plugins/insights/insights/webhook/

docs.title: Compatibility
docs.text: NetBox Version Plugin Version 4.0+ 1.0.0 4.4+ 1.0.0

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
Contributions are welcome, and they are greatly appreciated! Every little bit helps, and credit will always be given.

We love your input! We want to make contributing to this project as easy and transparent as possible, whether it's:

  • Reporting a bug
  • Discussing the current state of the code
  • Submitting a fix
  • Proposing new features
  • Becoming a maintainer

docs.title: General Tips for Working on GitHub
docs.text:
• Register for a free GitHub account if you haven't already.
  • You can use GitHub Markdown for formatting text and adding images.
  • To help mitigate notification spam, please avoid "bumping" issues with no activity. (To vote an issue up or down, use a or reaction.)
  • Please avoid pinging members with @ unless they've previously expressed interest or involvement with that particular issue.
  • Familiarize yourself with this list of discussion anti-patterns and make every effort to avoid them.

docs.title: Report Bugs
docs.text:
Report bugs at https://github.com/Dashton956-alt/netbox-insights-dashboard-plugin/issues.

If you are reporting a bug, please include:

  • Your operating system name and version.
  • Any details about your local setup that might be helpful in troubleshooting.
  • Detailed steps to reproduce the bug.

docs.title: Fix Bugs
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for bugs. Anything tagged with "bug" and "help wanted" is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Implement Features
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for features. Anything tagged with "enhancement" and "help wanted" is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Write Documentation
docs.text: NetBox insights-dashboard Plugin could always use more documentation, whether as part of the official NetBox insights-dashboard Plugin docs, in docstrings, or even on the web in blog posts, articles, and such.

docs.title: Submit Feedback
docs.text:
The best way to send feedback is to file an issue at https://github.com/Dashton956-alt/netbox-insights-dashboard-plugin/issues.

If you are proposing a feature:

  • Explain in detail how it would work.
  • Keep the scope as narrow as possible, to make it easier to implement.
  • Remember that this is a volunteer-driven project, and that contributions are welcome :)

docs.title: Get Started!
docs.text:
Ready to contribute? Here's how to set up netbox-insights-dashboard-plugin for local development.

  1. Fork the netbox-insights-dashboard-plugin repo on GitHub.

  2. Clone your fork locally

    $ git clone git@github.com:your_name_here/netbox-insights-dashboard-plugin.git

  3. Activate the NetBox virtual environment (see the NetBox documentation under Setting up a Development Environment):

    $ source ~/.venv/netbox/bin/activate

  4. Add the plugin to NetBox virtual environment in Develop mode (see Plugins Development):

    To ease development, it is recommended to go ahead and install the plugin at this point using setuptools' develop mode. This will create symbolic links within your Python environment to the plugin development directory. Call setup.py from the plugin's root directory with the develop argument (instead of install):

    $ python setup.py develop

  5. Create a branch for local development:

    $ git checkout -b name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature

    Now you can make your changes locally.

  6. Commit your changes and push your branch to GitHub:

    $ git add .
$ git commit -m "Your detailed description of your changes."
$ git push origin name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature

  7. Submit a pull request through the GitHub website.

docs.title: Pull Request Guidelines
docs.text:
Before you submit a pull request, check that it meets these guidelines:

  1. The pull request should include tests.
  2. If the pull request adds functionality, the docs should be updated. Put your new functionality into a function with a docstring, and add the feature to the list in README.md.
  3. The pull request should work for Python 3.8, 3.9, 3.10 and 3.11. Check https://github.com/Dashton956-alt/netbox-insights-dashboard-plugin/actions and make sure that the tests pass for all supported Python versions.

docs.title: Deploying
docs.text: A reminder for the maintainers on how to deploy. Make sure all your changes are committed (including an entry in CHANGELOG.md) and that all tests pass. Then in the github project go to Releases and create a new release with a new tag. This will automatically upload the release to pypi:
